elements.content: Using 4-pyridyl-1,2,4-triazole (pytrz) as ligand and a variety of copper(II) salts, nine copper(II) coordination polymers, {[Cu(pytrz)(OH)]X} n (X = Cl−, (1); Br−, (2); (NO3 −)·H2O, (3); BF4 −, (4); CF3SO3 −, (5)), {[Cu(pytrz)2](BF4)2·2H2O} n (6), {[Cu3(pytrz)2(OH)2(NO2)2(H2O)2](NO3)2·H2O} n (7), {[Cu3(pytrz)2(OH)2(H2O)2](SO4)2·10H2O} n (8), and {[Cu4(pytrz)4(OH)2(H2O)2](SiF6)3·11.5H2O} n (9), were prepared and their crystal structures were determined via single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Complexes 1−3 crystallize in a chiral space group P212121 and exhibits a three-dimensional (3D) chiral framework constructed by left-handed (CuO) n helixes (L). Complex 4 consists of (CuO) n helixes with the opposite chirality (R) and have the analogous cationic framework as 1. The structure of 5 is constructed through (CuO) n zigzag chains and represents the same (327583)(372) topology as 1−4. Complex 6 exhibits a novel two-dimensional (2D) Kagomé topology with bidentate pytrz. The structures of complexes 7 and 8 are based on trinuclear Cu3 clusters, and both display a 2D 44-net when only considering pytrz as bridges. In 7, the NO2 − anions act as bridges to connect the 44-nets to form a 3D α-polonium-type network. Complex 9 have four characteristically independent Cu2+ ions and construct a tetranuclear Cu4 cluster, and the Cu4 clusters are bridged by tridentate pytrz to form a 3D porous cationic coordination polymer.

elements.content: Nine novel copper(II) coordination polymers have been synthesized by using 4-pyridyl-1,2,4-triazole (pytrz) as a ligand and a variety of copper(II) salts, and their crystal structures were determined via single-crystal X-ray diffraction.
elements.clean_text: Nine novel copper(II) coordination polymers have been synthesized by using 4-pyridyl-1,2,4-triazole (pytrz) as a ligand and a variety of copper(II) salts, and their crystal structures were determined via single-crystal X-ray diffraction.

elements.content: The construction of metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) through crystal engineering has attracted tremendous attention, partly because of their intriguing molecular topologies for aesthetic appeal. Although a lot of MOFs with fantastic topological structures have been synthesized over the past two decades, rational and controlled preparation of such MOFs remains an outstanding challenge in crystal engineering. From the viewpoint of crystal engineering, the appropriate choice of organic building blocks and metal centers is the most effective and facile method to assemble MOFs with beautiful topologies. Cyano, caboxylate groups, pyridyl and triazole have been employed as organic linkers to bond with metal ions successfully. Among them, 1,2,4-triazole and its derivatives, which unite the coordination geometry of both pyrazoles and imidazoles, attract considerable interest in self-assembly of coordination networks.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The construction of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) through crystal engineering has attracted tremendous attention, partly because of their intriguing molecular topologies for aesthetic appeal. Although a lot of MOFs with fantastic topological structures have been synthesized over the past two decades, rational and controlled preparation of such MOFs remains an outstanding challenge in crystal engineering. From the viewpoint of crystal engineering, the appropriate choice of organic building blocks and metal centers is the most effective and facile method to assemble MOFs with beautiful topologies. Cyano, caboxylate groups, pyridyl and triazole have been employed as organic linkers to bond with metal ions successfully. Among them, 1,2,4-triazole and its derivatives, which unite the coordination geometry of both pyrazoles and imidazoles, attract considerable interest in self-assembly of coordination networks.

elements.content: Recently, it appears from the literature that anion-controlled self-assembly is one of the most useful strategies for producing fantastic metallosupramolecular architectures. It has been demonstrated that counteranions can play an important role in preparing MOFs, which can be divided into two key effects upon the structures of the final results. First, the anions, which can coordinate to metal cations, obviously influence the coordination sphere of the metal cations and hence the construction of framework. Second, the size of the anion can contribute to the pore diameter of the framework, and anions with a large size may prevent interpenetration to provide larger channels to accommodate anions.
elements.clean_text: Recently, it appears from the literature that anion-controlled self-assembly is one of the most useful strategies for producing fantastic metallosupramolecular architectures. It has been demonstrated that counteranions can play an important role in preparing MOFs, which can be divided into two key effects upon the structures of the final results. First, the anions, which can coordinate to metal cations, obviously influence the coordination sphere of the metal cations and hence the construction of framework. Second, the size of the anion can contribute to the pore diameter of the framework, and anions with a large size may prevent interpenetration to provide larger channels to accommodate anions.

elements.content: Previously, we reported a series of triazole-cadmium coordination polymers with different topologies tuned via different triazole ligands and anions. Also, the self-assembly of 1,2,4-triazole derivatives and Ag+ ions produced a lot of metal-rich silver(I) clusters. Recently, we employed 4-(3-pyridinyl)-1,2,4-triazole as a bridging ligand to self-assembe a series of complexes with the help of copper(II) ions and mixed anions, which represents the first successful conversion of a discrete cage into a three-dimensional (3D) coordination network based on a cage structure.
elements.clean_text: Previously, we reported a series of triazole-cadmium coordination polymers with different topologies tuned via different triazole ligands and anions. Also, the self-assembly of 1,2,4-triazole derivatives and Ag+ ions produced a lot of metal-rich silver(I) clusters. Recently, we employed 4-(3-pyridinyl)-1,2,4-triazole as a bridging ligand to self-assembe a series of complexes with the help of copper(II) ions and mixed anions, which represents the first successful conversion of a discrete cage into a three-dimensional (3D) coordination network based on a cage structure.

elements.content: Inspired by the aforementioned progress, we employ 4-(3-pyridinyl)-1,2,4-triazole (pytrz) as a ligand and copper(II) ion as a metal center to construct new complexes. There are two reasons for choosing pytrz as a ligand: (i) pytrz is a flexible ligand, and the triazole ring connects with pyridine ring through a single C−N bond, which can freely rotate according to the demand of coordination, making the dihedral angle between two rings in the range of 0−90° (Scheme ); (ii) the triazole ring is directly linked to a pyridine cycle at the N4 atom, and the pyridine-N atom is at the 3-positon, which is effective in forming polydentate fashion and results in fantastic topological structures. With the influence of different counteranions, nine copper(II) complexes, namely, {[Cu(pytrz)(OH)]X} n (X = Cl−, (1); Br−, (2); (NO3 −)·H2O, (3); BF4 −, (4); CF3SO3 −, (5)), {[Cu(pytrz)2](BF4)2·2H2O} n (6), {[Cu3(pytrz)2(OH)2(NO2)2(H2O)2](NO3)2·H2O} n (7), {[Cu3(pytrz)2(OH)2(H2O)2](SO4)2·7H2O} n (8), and {[Cu4(pytrz)4(OH)2(H2O)2](SiF6)3·11.5H2O} n (9), were obtained and characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, which exhibited novel topologies with two-dimensional (2D) and 3D structures.

elements.content: The triazole ligand pytrz was synthesized according to the literature method. All other reagents were commercially available and used without further purification. The C, H, and N microanalyses were carried out with a Perkin-Elmer 240 elemental analyzer. Thermal analyses (under oxygenated atmosphere, heating rate of 5 °C min−1) were carried out in a Labsys NETZSCH TG 209 Setaram apparatus. The CD spectra in KBr pellets were carried out on a Jasco J-715−150S circular dichroism spectrometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials

The triazole ligand pytrz was synthesized according to the literature method. All other reagents were commercially available and used without further purification. The C, H, and N microanalyses were carried out with a Perkin-Elmer 240 elemental analyzer. Thermal analyses (under oxygenated atmosphere, heating rate of 5 °C min-1) were carried out in a Labsys NETZSCH TG 209 Setaram apparatus. The CD spectra in KBr pellets were carried out on a Jasco J-715-150S circular dichroism spectrometer.

elements.content: Five compounds were obtained following the same method, and the mixture of pytrz (0.3 mmol), salts of copper(II) (CuBr2, CuCl2, Cu(BF4)2, Cu(NO3)2 and Cu(CF3SO3)2) (0.3 mmol) was stirred in H2O (10 mL) and CH3CN (5 mL) for 1 h (pH = 5). Upon slow evaporation of the filtrate at room temperature for two weeks (pH = 5 expect filtrate 2 pH = 7), well-shaped blue-stick crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained. Yield: 60, 56, 57, 62 and 39% based on the Cu2+ salts, respectively. Elemental analysis calcd (%) for C7H7ClCuN4O (1): C, 32.07; H, 2.69; N, 21. 37. Found: C, 32.24; H, 2.56; N, 21. 49. Elemental analysis calcd (%) for C7H7BrCuN4O (2): C, 27.42; H, 2.30; N, 18.27. Found: C, 27.54; H, 2.39; N, 18.06. Elemental analysis calcd (%) for C7H9CuN5O5 (3): C, 27.41; H, 2.96; N, 22.83. Found: C, 27.68; H, 2.82; N, 22.49. Elemental analysis calcd (%) for C7H7BCuF4N4O (4): C, 26.82; H, 2.25; N, 17.87. Found: C, 26.68; H, 2.02; N, 17.56. Elemental analysis calcd (%) for C8H7CuF3N4O4S (5): C, 25.57; H, 1.88; N, 14.91. Found: C, 25.39; H, 2.06; N, 14.77.

Upon slow evaporation of the filtrate at room temperature for two weeks (pH = 5 expect filtrate 2 pH = 7), well-shaped blue-stick crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained. elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction measurements of 1−9 were carried out with a Bruker Smart CCD diffractometer and an APEX II CCD area detector equipped with a graphite crystal monochromator situated in the incident beam for data collection at 293(2) and 294(2) K. Lorentz polarization and absorption corrections were applied. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques using the SHELXS-97 and SHELXL-97 programs. Anisotropic thermal parameters were assigned to all non-hydrogen atoms. The hydrogen atoms were placed in idealized positions and located in the difference Fourier map. The crystallographic data structure refinements for 1−9 are listed in Tables and , respectively. CCDC-610484 (1), -692966 (2), -266090 (3), -610483 (4), -266087 (5), -692967 (6), -692968 (7), -266089 (8), and -692969 (9) contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.
elements.clean_text:
Crystallographic Studies

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction measurements of 1-9 were carried out with a Bruker Smart CCD diffractometer and an APEX II CCD area detector equipped with a graphite crystal monochromator situated in the incident beam for data collection at 293(2) and 294(2) K. Lorentz polarization and absorption corrections were applied. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques using the SHELXS-97 and SHELXL-97 programs. Anisotropic thermal parameters were assigned to all non-hydrogen atoms. The hydrogen atoms were placed in idealized positions and located in the difference Fourier map. The crystallographic data structure refinements for 1-9 are listed in Tables  and , respectively. CCDC-610484 (1), -692966 (2), -266090 (3), -610483 (4), -266087 (5), -692967 (6), -692968 (7), -266089 (8), and -692969 (9) contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses reveal that nine complexes consist of two parts: cationic complex and counterion. In nine complexes, pytrz ligands coordinate to the Cu2+ ions in two modes: bridging bidentate (A) or tridentate (B) (Scheme ), and only complex 6 adopts bidentate pytrz ligands, while all other complexes with tridentate pytrz ligands. All the Cu−N bond lengths are comparable to those found for Cu2+ complexes.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses reveal that nine complexes consist of two parts: cationic complex and counterion. In nine complexes, pytrz ligands coordinate to the Cu2+ ions in two modes: bridging bidentate (A) or tridentate (B) (Scheme ), and only complex 6 adopts bidentate pytrz ligands, while all other complexes with tridentate pytrz ligands. All the Cu-N bond lengths are comparable to those found for Cu2+ complexes.

elements.content:
<fig fig-type="scheme" id="sch2" orientation="portrait" position="float">
<label>2</label>
<caption>
<title>Coordination Modes of pytrz in Complexes <bold>1</bold>−<bold>9</bold>: Bridging Bidentate (<bold>A</bold>) and Tridentate</title>
</caption>
<graphic id="gs2" orientation="portrait" position="anchor" xlink:href="cg-2008-00719u_0007.tif"></graphic>
</fig>
elements.clean_text: 2  Coordination Modes of pytrz in Complexes 1-9: Bridging Bidentate (A) and Tridentate

elements.content: Complexes 1−4crystallize in a chiral space group P212121 and the Cu2+ ions have a similar coordination environment, as shown in Figure . In 1−4, Cu1 ion is five-coordinated with three nitrogen atoms from one pyridyl and two triazole rings and two hydroxyl groups to form a distorted square-pyramid, and N1A, N2, O1, and O1A compose the equatorial plane, while N4B at the axial site. Adjacent Cu2+ ions are bound by hydroxyl groups to form a chiral (CuO) n helix (Figure ). The angles of O−Cu−O and Cu−O−Cu are 166.12, 120.38 Å for 1; 163.63, 120.43 Å for 2; 171.71, 120.64 for 3 and 162.36, 120.95 Å for 4 and the shortest distance of Cu···Cu in 1−4 are 3.327, 3.337, 3.382, and 3.346, respectively. Complex 1−3 has left-handed (L) (CuO) n helix (Figure a), while 4 has the opposite chiral, namely, right-handed (R) (CuO) n helix (Figure b). The pitches for 1−4 are 6.592, 6.590, 6.742, and 6.592 Å, respectively. There is only one crystallographically independent pytrz ligand with tridentate mode in 1−4, and the dihedral angles of pyridyl and triazole cycles are 28.8°, 31.7°, 81.0°, and 41.1°, respectively. Each helical chain links four others through pytrz spacers to form a homochiral 3D cationic framework. There are 1D channels formed within the cationic framework of 1, 2, and 4 along the a axis, and for 3, the channels run parallel to the crystallographical a and c axis (Figure ). In 1, 2 and 4, the counteranions are situated in the channels along a axis with hydrogen bonding intereactions to OH− (Figure a), while the NO3 − anions in 3 are hosted in the channels along the c axis with weak Cu···O bonds (2.881 Å) (Figure b).
elements.clean_text:
3D Homochiral (1-4) and Noncentrosymmetric (5) Frameworks

Complexes 1-4crystallize in a chiral space group P212121 and the Cu2+ ions have a similar coordination environment, as shown in Figure . In 1-4, Cu1 ion is five-coordinated with three nitrogen atoms from one pyridyl and two triazole rings and two hydroxyl groups to form a distorted square-pyramid, and N1A, N2, O1, and O1A compose the equatorial plane, while N4B at the axial site. Adjacent Cu2+ ions are bound by hydroxyl groups to form a chiral (CuO) n  helix (Figure ). The angles of O-Cu-O and Cu-O-Cu are 166.12, 120.38 Å for 1; 163.63, 120.43 Å for 2; 171.71, 120.64 for 3 and 162.36, 120.95 Å for 4 and the shortest distance of Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu in 1-4 are 3.327, 3.337, 3.382, and 3.346, respectively. Complex 1-3 has left-handed (L) (CuO) n  helix (Figure a), while 4 has the opposite chiral, namely, right-handed (R) (CuO) n  helix (Figure b). The pitches for 1-4 are 6.592, 6.590, 6.742, and 6.592 Å, respectively. There is only one crystallographically independent pytrz ligand with tridentate mode in 1-4, and the dihedral angles of pyridyl and triazole cycles are 28.8°, 31.7°, 81.0°, and 41.1°, respectively. Each helical chain links four others through pytrz spacers to form a homochiral 3D cationic framework. There are 1D channels formed within the cationic framework of 1, 2, and 4 along the a axis, and for 3, the channels run parallel to the crystallographical a and c axis (Figure ). In 1, 2 and 4, the counteranions are situated in the channels along a axis with hydrogen bonding intereactions to OH- (Figure a), while the NO3 - anions in 3 are hosted in the channels along the c axis with weak Cu⋅⋅⋅O bonds (2.881 Å) (Figure b).

elements.content: Cu1 ion in 5 is five-coordinated as that in 1−4; however, the coordination geometry is different from that of 1−4 and conforms close to a trigonal bipyramid with N1A, N2, N4B at the equatorial plane and O1, O1A at the axial sites with the O1−Cu1−O1A angle of 176.74°, as shown in Figure . As a result, complex 5 crystallizes in the monoclinic system, noncentrosymmetric space group Cc but not P212121 as 1−4. The Cu2+ ions are connected through O atoms from hydroxyl groups to construct a zigzag (CuO) n chain (Figure ), while the angle of Cu−O−Cu is 125.02° and the shortest distance of Cu···Cu is 3.377 Å. The connectivity of (CuO) n chains is similar to that of 1−4, while the dihedral angle of triazole and pyridyl cycles is 86.6° close to orthogonal. As a result of this connectivity pattern, the (CuO) n chains are further linked to form a 3D porous cationic framework, and 1D channels are formed parallel to the crystallographic c axis and host CF3SO3 − anions (Figure ).

elements.content: The circular dichroism CD spectra measured in KBr pellets exhibits obvious cotton effects, which further confirm the enantiomeric nature of the optically active complexes 1−4 (). Thermal gravimetric analyses of 1−5 reveal that the complexes are stable below 200 °C. The coordination networks are decomposed at higher temperature (). Although complexes 1−5 have analogous cationic structures, thermal properties are different under the influence of counter-anions.

elements.content: Complex 6 displays a novel 2D Kagomé topology, as shown in Figure . Cu1 ion coordinates with four nitrogen atoms from two pyridyl and two triazole rings, forming a quadrangle, and the bond lengths of Cu1−Npyridyl and Cu1−Ntriazole are 2.043 and 2.010 Å, respectively. The departure of Cu1 ion from the quadrangle is 0.02 Å, and then Cu1 ion and four nitrogen atoms around it are considered to be coplanar. Two water molecules at the axial sites of quadrangle weakly coordinate to Cu1 ion with bond length of 2.458 Å and angle of 174.82°, and the overall coordination geometry of Cu1 ion conforms close to a slightly distorted octahedron (Figure a). Each Cu2+ ion connected another four Cu2+ ions through four bidentate pytrz ligands, and a 2D cationic planar structure is formed, in which all the Cu2+ ions are coplanar (Figure b). In this 2D structure, two kinds of building blocks exist: Cu3(pytrz)3 and Cu6(pytrz)6, and two disordered BF4 − anions locate in Cu3(pytrz)3, while six normal BF4 − anions in Cu6(pytrz)6.

2D Kagomé Topology (6)

Complex 6 displays a novel 2D Kagomé topology, as shown in Figure . Cu1 ion coordinates with four nitrogen atoms from two pyridyl and two triazole rings, forming a quadrangle, and the bond lengths of Cu1-Npyridyl and Cu1-Ntriazole are 2.043 and 2.010 Å, respectively. The departure of Cu1 ion from the quadrangle is 0.02 Å, and then Cu1 ion and four nitrogen atoms around it are considered to be coplanar. Two water molecules at the axial sites of quadrangle weakly coordinate to Cu1 ion with bond length of 2.458 Å and angle of 174.82°, and the overall coordination geometry of Cu1 ion conforms close to a slightly distorted octahedron (Figure a). Each Cu2+ ion connected another four Cu2+ ions through four bidentate pytrz ligands, and a 2D cationic planar structure is formed, in which all the Cu2+ ions are coplanar (Figure b). In this 2D structure, two kinds of building blocks exist: Cu3(pytrz)3 and Cu6(pytrz)6, and two disordered BF4 - anions locate in Cu3(pytrz)3, while six normal BF4 - anions in Cu6(pytrz)6.

elements.content: Complexes 7 and 8 crystallize in the monoclinic space group P21/n, and both construct a linear trinuclear Cu3 cluster as the secondary building block, as shown in Figure . There are two crystallographically independent Cu2+ ions (Cu1 and Cu2) in 7 and 8, which is in the molar ratio of 2:1, and Cu2 ion connect two Cu1 ions through two μ2-OH bridges to form a trinuclear Cu3 cluster. In 7, Cu1 is coordinated by two oxygen atoms from hydroxyl group (O1) and NO2 − anion (O3), two nitrogen atoms form pyridyl and triazole rings, while Cu2 coordinates with two hydroxyl groups (O1, O1A) and two nitrogen atoms from two triazole rings (N1, N1A). The average bond lengths of Cu1−O (1.946 Å) and Cu1−N (2.029 Å) are slightly longer than those associated with Cu2 (1.889, 2.008 Å). The weak Cu1···O2 bond (2.286 Å) is at the axial site, which make the coordination geometry around Cu1 close to a distorted square-pyramid, while O4 and O4A weakly coordinated to Cu2 with the bond length of 2.567 Å form a elongated octahedral geometry (Figure left). The coordination environment of Cu2+ ions in 8 is similar to those in 7, and only Cu1 is weakly coordinated to another one sulfate oxygen atom (O5), and then Cu1 in 8 adopts a slightly distorted octahedral geometry (Figure right). The angles of Cu1···Cu2···Cu1A are 180° in 7 and 8. Each trinuclear Cu3 cluster linked four Cu3 clusters through four μ3-pytrz ligands to form a 2D layer (Figure ), and the dihedral angles of pyridyl and triazol rings are 34.6° and 38.0° for 7 and 8, respectively. In 7, the 2D sheets are connected through weak Cu···O (NO2 −) bonds to form a 3D porous structure and the NO3 − anions exist in the channels along the b axis (Figure ). In 8, the 2D sheets are not linked to form a 3D structure like 7, and the disordered SO4 2− ions are connected in the cavity along the c axis through weak Cu···O (SO4 2−) bonds (Figure b).

2D Sheet Based on Trinuclear Cu3 Clusters (7 and 8)

Complexes 7 and 8 crystallize in the monoclinic space group P21/n, and both construct a linear trinuclear Cu3 cluster as the secondary building block, as shown in Figure . There are two crystallographically independent Cu2+ ions (Cu1 and Cu2) in 7 and 8, which is in the molar ratio of 2:1, and Cu2 ion connect two Cu1 ions through two μ2-OH bridges to form a trinuclear Cu3 cluster. In 7, Cu1 is coordinated by two oxygen atoms from hydroxyl group (O1) and NO2 - anion (O3), two nitrogen atoms form pyridyl and triazole rings, while Cu2 coordinates with two hydroxyl groups (O1, O1A) and two nitrogen atoms from two triazole rings (N1, N1A). The average bond lengths of Cu1-O (1.946 Å) and Cu1-N (2.029 Å) are slightly longer than those associated with Cu2 (1.889, 2.008 Å). The weak Cu1⋅⋅⋅O2 bond (2.286 Å) is at the axial site, which make the coordination geometry around Cu1 close to a distorted square-pyramid, while O4 and O4A weakly coordinated to Cu2 with the bond length of 2.567 Å form a elongated octahedral geometry (Figure  left). The coordination environment of Cu2+ ions in 8 is similar to those in 7, and only Cu1 is weakly coordinated to another one sulfate oxygen atom (O5), and then Cu1 in 8 adopts a slightly distorted octahedral geometry (Figure  right). The angles of Cu1⋅⋅⋅Cu2⋅⋅⋅Cu1A are 180° in 7 and 8. Each trinuclear Cu3 cluster linked four Cu3 clusters through four μ3-pytrz ligands to form a 2D layer (Figure ), and the dihedral angles of pyridyl and triazol rings are 34.6° and 38.0° for 7 and 8, respectively. In 7, the 2D sheets are connected through weak Cu⋅⋅⋅O (NO2 -) bonds to form a 3D porous structure and the NO3 - anions exist in the channels along the b axis (Figure ). In 8, the 2D sheets are not linked to form a 3D structure like 7, and the disordered SO4 2- ions are connected in the cavity along the c axis through weak Cu⋅⋅⋅O (SO4 2-) bonds (Figure b).

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis shows that 9 is a 3D coordination polymer and crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c. Four crystallographically independent Cu2+ ions (Cu1, Cu2, Cu3, and Cu4) are bridged by four pytrz ligands and two μ2-OH to form a tetranuclear Cu4 cluster, as shown in Figure . Cu1 and Cu4 are coordinated by one μ2-OH and three nitrogen atoms from one triazole and two pyridyl rings at the equatorial sites, and the average Cu1−O and Cu1−N distances are 1.912 and 2.039 Å, while those of Cu4−O and Cu4−N are 1.893 and 2.047 Å. Two water molecules (O4, O5) at the axial sites weakly coordinated with Cu1, while one water molecule (O6) at the axial site of Cu4, and the average distances of Cu1−O and Cu4−O are 2.520 and 2.218 Å, respectively. The equatorial sites of Cu2 and Cu3 are similar, which is formed by one μ2-OH and three triazole nitrogen atoms. The average bond lengths of Cu2−O and Cu2−N are 1.892 and 2.007 Å, which are slightly shorter than those of Cu3−O and Cu3−N (1.912, 2.008 Å). O3 at the axial site complete the coordination sphere of Cu2, while O3 and O7 at the axial sites of Cu3, and the average bong lengths of Cu2−O and Cu3−O are 2.461 and 2.536 Å. The coordination geometries of Cu1 and Cu3 conform close to an elongated octahedron, while that of Cu2 and Cu4 is a square-pyramid. The distances of Cu1···Cu2, Cu2···Cu3 and Cu3···Cu4 are 3.365, 3.529, and 3.251 Å, and the angle of Cu1···Cu2···Cu3 and Cu2···Cu3···Cu4 are 147.19° and 154.38°. The tetranuclear Cu4 clusters are connected through two kinds of μ3-pytrz ligands to form a 1D chain (Figure ), and the dihedral angles of pyridyl and triazole rings are 28.7° and 32.2°. This chain is viewed along the b direction as a ladder (Figure a), and shows a 1D small channel along the a direction (Figure b). Those chains are connected by two other kinds of μ3-pytrz ligands to form a 3D porous framework, which exhibits two types of pores (A and B) (Figure ) and the dihedral angles of pyridyl and triazole rings are 39.2° and 40.9°. The counteranions (SiF6 −) locate in the two types of pores, and the mole ratio of SiF6 2− anions in A and B is 1:2.

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis shows that 9 is a 3D coordination polymer and crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c. Four crystallographically independent Cu2+ ions (Cu1, Cu2, Cu3, and Cu4) are bridged by four pytrz ligands and two μ2-OH to form a tetranuclear Cu4 cluster, as shown in Figure . Cu1 and Cu4 are coordinated by one μ2-OH and three nitrogen atoms from one triazole and two pyridyl rings at the equatorial sites, and the average Cu1-O and Cu1-N distances are 1.912 and 2.039 Å, while those of Cu4-O and Cu4-N are 1.893 and 2.047 Å. Two water molecules (O4, O5) at the axial sites weakly coordinated with Cu1, while one water molecule (O6) at the axial site of Cu4, and the average distances of Cu1-O and Cu4-O are 2.520 and 2.218 Å, respectively. The equatorial sites of Cu2 and Cu3 are similar, which is formed by one μ2-OH and three triazole nitrogen atoms. The average bond lengths of Cu2-O and Cu2-N are 1.892 and 2.007 Å, which are slightly shorter than those of Cu3-O and Cu3-N (1.912, 2.008 Å). O3 at the axial site complete the coordination sphere of Cu2, while O3 and O7 at the axial sites of Cu3, and the average bong lengths of Cu2-O and Cu3-O are 2.461 and 2.536 Å. The coordination geometries of Cu1 and Cu3 conform close to an elongated octahedron, while that of Cu2 and Cu4 is a square-pyramid. The distances of Cu1⋅⋅⋅Cu2, Cu2⋅⋅⋅Cu3 and Cu3⋅⋅⋅Cu4 are 3.365, 3.529, and 3.251 Å, and the angle of Cu1⋅⋅⋅Cu2⋅⋅⋅Cu3 and Cu2⋅⋅⋅Cu3⋅⋅⋅Cu4 are 147.19° and 154.38°. The tetranuclear Cu4 clusters are connected through two kinds of μ3-pytrz ligands to form a 1D chain (Figure ), and the dihedral angles of pyridyl and triazole rings are 28.7° and 32.2°. This chain is viewed along the b direction as a ladder (Figure a), and shows a 1D small channel along the a direction (Figure b). Those chains are connected by two other kinds of μ3-pytrz ligands to form a 3D porous framework, which exhibits two types of pores (A and B) (Figure ) and the dihedral angles of pyridyl and triazole rings are 39.2° and 40.9°. The counteranions (SiF6 -) locate in the two types of pores, and the mole ratio of SiF6 2- anions in A and B is 1:2.

elements.content: From the above description, it is clear that the choice of anions plays an important role in determining the topological structures of the resultant complexes. The reaction containing the single univalent anions (Cl−, Br−, NO3 −, BF4 −) resulted in products with isomorphic cationic structure (1−4), which crystallized in a chiral space group P212121 and consisted of a 3D chiral framework with left-hand (L) (1−3) or right-hand (R) (4). When a larger univalent anion (CF3SO3 −) is substituted for the above-mentioned anions, the basical topology of 5 is analogous to that of 1−4 and is described as a Schläfli symbol (327583)(372) net (see below for a discussion of topological representations). However, the coordination geometry of Cu2+ ion is close to a trigonal bipyramid but not a square-pyramid as that in 1−4, and then the resultant 5 forms a 3D framework with channels of larger pore diameter to accommodate CF3SO3 − anions. When the guest molecules are removed, calculations from the X-ray structure parameters determined by PLATON show that there are approximately 9.4, 14.7 25.2, 32.2, and 36.8% void space per unit volume for 1−5, respectively, which is consistent with the anionic volume on going from Cl− → Br− → NO3 − → BF4 − → CF3SO3 −. The frameworks with channels of different pore diameter, which accommodate counteranions, stressed the significant influence of the size of counteranions upon the network architectures. Adding another anion in the systems of BF4 − or NO3 −, we obtained absolutely different frameworks. When adding NaNO3 to the system of pytrz and Cu(BF4)2, complex 6 was obtained with a 2D Kagomé topology, and NO3 − anions were absent in the structure, which indicated that NO3 − acted as anion template. Addition of NaNO2 to the system of pytrz and Cu(NO3)2 resulted in complex 7, NO2 − anions coordinated to Cu2+ ions, while NO3 − acted as counteranions in the channels. The incorporation of bivalent anions obtained another framework. The system containing SO4 2− anions resulted in complex 8 with a 2D grid-like structure, and complex 9 is synthesized by the reaction of Cu(BF4)2 and Na2SiF6, which constructed a 3D framework based on tetranuclear units.
elements.clean_text:
The Role of the Anions

From the above description, it is clear that the choice of anions plays an important role in determining the topological structures of the resultant complexes. The reaction containing the single univalent anions (Cl-, Br-, NO3 -, BF4 -) resulted in products with isomorphic cationic structure (1-4), which crystallized in a chiral space group P212121 and consisted of a 3D chiral framework with left-hand (L) (1-3) or right-hand (R) (4). When a larger univalent anion (CF3SO3 -) is substituted for the above-mentioned anions, the basical topology of 5 is analogous to that of 1-4 and is described as a Schläfli symbol (327583)(372) net (see below for a discussion of topological representations). However, the coordination geometry of Cu2+ ion is close to a trigonal bipyramid but not a square-pyramid as that in 1-4, and then the resultant 5 forms a 3D framework with channels of larger pore diameter to accommodate CF3SO3 - anions. When the guest molecules are removed, calculations from the X-ray structure parameters determined by PLATON show that there are approximately 9.4, 14.7 25.2, 32.2, and 36.8% void space per unit volume for 1-5, respectively, which is consistent with the anionic volume on going from Cl- → Br- → NO3 - → BF4 - → CF3SO3 -. The frameworks with channels of different pore diameter, which accommodate counteranions, stressed the significant influence of the size of counteranions upon the network architectures. Adding another anion in the systems of BF4 - or NO3 -, we obtained absolutely different frameworks. When adding NaNO3 to the system of pytrz and Cu(BF4)2, complex 6 was obtained with a 2D Kagomé topology, and NO3 - anions were absent in the structure, which indicated that NO3 - acted as anion template. Addition of NaNO2 to the system of pytrz and Cu(NO3)2 resulted in complex 7, NO2 - anions coordinated to Cu2+ ions, while NO3 - acted as counteranions in the channels. The incorporation of bivalent anions obtained another framework. The system containing SO4 2- anions resulted in complex 8 with a 2D grid-like structure, and complex 9 is synthesized by the reaction of Cu(BF4)2 and Na2SiF6, which constructed a 3D framework based on tetranuclear units.

elements.content: For 1−5, considering the tridentate pytrz as a three-connected node, two kinds of nodes exist in the framework (Cu2+ ion and pytrz). Some unique shortest three-, seven-, and eight-membered circuits through nodes are found in 1−5. For Cu1, two μ2-OH bridges and three tridentate pytrz construct the five edges. The pair of two μ2-OH bridges is contained in a seven-membered ring, and each of three pairs of pytrz nodes is contained in an eight-membered ring, while the pairs of OH bridge and pytrz are contained in two three- and four seven-membered rings. Thus, the Cu ion has the Schläfli symbol 327583. For pytrz, the pairs of three edges are contained in three- and seven-membered rings. The molar ratio of these two kinds of nodes is 1:1, and thus the network of 1−5 can be symbolized as an Archimedean-type (327583)(372) net with five- and three-connected nodes (Figure ). Although 5 has the same Schläfli symbol (327583)(372) as that of 1−4 (Figure a), for the difference from an achiral (CuO) n chain in 5 to chiral (CuO) n chain in 1−4, the topology structure of 5 is significantly different from that of 1−4 in appearance (Figure b).

Topological Representations

For 1-5, considering the tridentate pytrz as a three-connected node, two kinds of nodes exist in the framework (Cu2+ ion and pytrz). Some unique shortest three-, seven-, and eight-membered circuits through nodes are found in 1-5. For Cu1, two μ2-OH bridges and three tridentate pytrz construct the five edges. The pair of two μ2-OH bridges is contained in a seven-membered ring, and each of three pairs of pytrz nodes is contained in an eight-membered ring, while the pairs of OH bridge and pytrz are contained in two three- and four seven-membered rings. Thus, the Cu ion has the Schläfli symbol 327583. For pytrz, the pairs of three edges are contained in three- and seven-membered rings. The molar ratio of these two kinds of nodes is 1:1, and thus the network of 1-5 can be symbolized as an Archimedean-type (327583)(372) net with five- and three-connected nodes (Figure ). Although 5 has the same Schläfli symbol (327583)(372) as that of 1-4 (Figure a), for the difference from an achiral (CuO) n  chain in 5 to chiral (CuO) n  chain in 1-4, the topology structure of 5 is significantly different from that of 1-4 in appearance (Figure b).

The Cu···Cu edge length is 8.667 Å, and the triangle is perfect with an angle of 60°, while the hexagon with two kinds of angles (95.32° and 144.68°).

elements.content: The structure of 7 and 8 can be simplified by treating trinuclear Cu3 cluster as a whole. Each Cu3 cluster is linked to four neighbors (by a number of pytrz ligands) and appears to be a net point for cationic four-connected 2D 44-net sheet (Figure a). The lengths of quadrangle are 10.768 and 10.379 Å for 7 and 8, and the angles are 121.92°, 58.08° for 7 and 122.25°, 57.75° for 8. In 7, the parallel series of 44-nets are interconnected by the second bridges (NO2 −) and the internetwork distance is 6.921 Å. Ignoring the difference in the bridges, the 3D structure is analogous to the α-polonium-type network and has 41263 topology based on trinuclear Cu3 clusters (Figure b).

elements.content: If the tetranuclear Cu4 cluster in 9 is considered as a node, each node is coordinated with eight μ3-pytrz ligands, in which four μ3-pytrz ligands chelate with Cu2 or Cu3 and another four chelate to Cu1 or Cu4. Each of the former kinds of ligands connects one Cu4 cluster, while each two of the latter kind of ligands connect one Cu4 cluster. In this way, each node links six close neighbors and appears to be a net point for a cationic six-connected 3D framework. The overall topology supplied by the tetranuclear Cu4 clusters can be symbolized as (33435762) net (Figure ).
elements.clean_text: If the tetranuclear Cu4 cluster in 9 is considered as a node, each node is coordinated with eight μ3-pytrz ligands, in which four μ3-pytrz ligands chelate with Cu2 or Cu3 and another four chelate to Cu1 or Cu4. Each of the former kinds of ligands connects one Cu4 cluster, while each two of the latter kind of ligands connect one Cu4 cluster. In this way, each node links six close neighbors and appears to be a net point for a cationic six-connected 3D framework. The overall topology supplied by the tetranuclear Cu4 clusters can be symbolized as (33435762) net (Figure ).

elements.content: In comparison with the reported MOF constructed from a copper(II) ion and 1,2,4-triazole ligands, the dihedral angles between pyridyl and triazole rings (Scheme ) and the coordination environment of copper(II) ion are also important to construct the topological structure. It is interesting that the dihedral angles between the pyridyl and triazole plane vary from 28.7° to 86.6° in this series of compounds. The dihedral angles of most compounds (except 3 and 5 in 1−9) are similar to those of the reported complex [Cu3(pytrz)10(H2O)2](ClO4)6·7H2O. However, the larger values (81.0° for 3 and 86.6° for 5) are near 90°, which was also observed in our reported compound {[Cu3(μ3-pytrz)3(μ3-O)(H2O)3](ClO4)2.5(BF4)1.5·5.25H2O} n previously. The coordination environments of copper(II) ions are five-coordinated in 1−5 and six-coordinated for 6−9, respectively. The six-coordinated copper(II) ions are common in triazole-Cu(II) systems. The coordination geometries of five-coordinated complexes 1−5 could be determined by τ equation. According to the equation τ = (β − α)/60, where α and β are the bond angles involving the trans donor atoms in the basal plane, τ = 0 is for square pyramidal (SP) geometry and τ = 1 is for trigonal bipyramidal (TBP) geometry. The τ values of 1−5 are 0.09, 0.14, 0.01, 0.14, and 0.60, respectively. Copper(II) ions formed a distorted square-pyramid in 1−4 similar to that of complexes [Cu3(trz)4(H2O)3]F2 and [Cu4(datrz)2(OH)2(SO4)2]. But in 5, the coordination geometry is a trigonal bipyramid.

It is interesting that the dihedral angles between the pyridyl and triazole plane vary from 28.7° to 86.6° in this series of compounds. The dihedral angles of most compounds (except 3 and 5 in 1-9) are similar to those of the reported complex [Cu3(pytrz)10(H2O)2](ClO4)6⋅7H2O. However, the larger values (81.0° for 3 and 86.6° for 5) are near 90°, which was also observed in our reported compound {[Cu3(μ3-pytrz)3(μ3-O)(H2O)3](ClO4)2.5(BF4)1.5⋅5.25H2O} n  previously. The coordination environments of copper(II) ions are five-coordinated in 1-5 and six-coordinated for 6-9, respectively. The six-coordinated copper(II) ions are common in triazole-Cu(II) systems. The coordination geometries of five-coordinated complexes 1-5 could be determined by τ equation. According to the equation τ = (β - α)/60, where α and β are the bond angles involving the trans donor atoms in the basal plane, τ = 0 is for square pyramidal (SP) geometry and τ = 1 is for trigonal bipyramidal (TBP) geometry. The τ values of 1-5 are 0.09, 0.14, 0.01, 0.14, and 0.60, respectively. Copper(II) ions formed a distorted square-pyramid in 1-4 similar to that of complexes [Cu3(trz)4(H2O)3]F2 and [Cu4(datrz)2(OH)2(SO4)2]. But in 5, the coordination geometry is a trigonal bipyramid.

elements.content: In summary, we have investigated a series of triazole-copper(II) complexes with novel topological structures, which represent a continued investigation of the coordination chemistry of triazole ligands. Complexes 1−4 crystallize in a chiral space group P212121 and exhibit chiral 3D frameworks, and complexes 1−3 consist of left-handed (CuO) n helixes, while complex 4 with the opposite chirality. In contrast to a vast number of triazole-copper(II) coordination polymers, only a few chiral examples have been reported. When the counteranion was replaced by CF3SO3 − anion, complex 5 was isolated with a (CuO) n zigzag chain, which represented the same Schläfli symbol (327583)(372) as those in 1−4. With the help of mixed univalent-anions, complexes 6 and 7 are obtained, in which 6 exhibits analogous Kagomé lattice topology and 7 has a α-polonium-type network based on trinuclear Cu3 clusters. Complex 8 was synthesized with the influence of a bivalent anion (SO4 2−), which is constructed through trinuclear Cu3 clusters to form a 2D 44-net. With the incorporation of one univalent anion and one bivalent anion in a one-pot reaction, a novel complex 9 based on tetranuclear Cu4 clusters resulted. The results imply that counteranions play an important role in the construction of the frameworks.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, we have investigated a series of triazole-copper(II) complexes with novel topological structures, which represent a continued investigation of the coordination chemistry of triazole ligands. Complexes 1-4 crystallize in a chiral space group P212121 and exhibit chiral 3D frameworks, and complexes 1-3 consist of left-handed (CuO) n  helixes, while complex 4 with the opposite chirality. In contrast to a vast number of triazole-copper(II) coordination polymers, only a few chiral examples have been reported. When the counteranion was replaced by CF3SO3 - anion, complex 5 was isolated with a (CuO) n  zigzag chain, which represented the same Schläfli symbol (327583)(372) as those in 1-4. With the help of mixed univalent-anions, complexes 6 and 7 are obtained, in which 6 exhibits analogous Kagomé lattice topology and 7 has a α-polonium-type network based on trinuclear Cu3 clusters. Complex 8 was synthesized with the influence of a bivalent anion (SO4 2-), which is constructed through trinuclear Cu3 clusters to form a 2D 44-net. With the incorporation of one univalent anion and one bivalent anion in a one-pot reaction, a novel complex 9 based on tetranuclear Cu4 clusters resulted. The results imply that counteranions play an important role in the construction of the frameworks.
